title-group.article-title: Brevianthrones, bianthrones from a Chinese isolate of the endophytic fungus Colletotrichum brevisporum

kwd.tp:taxon-name: Plasmodium falciparum ( Ndjakou Lenta et al., 2008 )

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Brevianthrones, bianthrones from a Chinese isolate of the endophytic fungus
Colletotrichum brevisporum

Min Lin a , Donovon A. Adpressa b , Meiyu Feng a , Ya Lu a , Benjamin R. Clark
a, *

a
School of Pharmaceutical Science and Technology, Tianjin University, 92 Weijin Road, Tianjin , 300092, People’ s Republic of China

b Department of Analytical Research and Development, Merck &
Co., Inc. Boston, MA, 02115, United States
A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Structure elucidation
Bianthrones
Anthraquinones
Plant-derived fungus
A B S T R A C T

Seven undescribed bianthrones, the brevianthrones, together with two known anthraquinones, were isolated from the plant-derived fungus
Colletotrichum brevisporum
, obtained from the plant
Piper sarmentosum Roxb.
, collected in Guangxi , China . This is the first report of the isolation of bianthrones from the
Colletotrichum
genus. The structures of the compounds were elucidated by a combination of NMR and MS spectroscopic analysis, while the absolute configurations were determined by X-ray crystallography and by simulation of ECD spectra.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
During the investigation of a Chinese isolate of the endophytic fungus
Colletotrichum brevisporum PSSF
01 ( Glomerellaceae ), we have isolated seven undescribed bianthrones, together with two known anthraquinones. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first paper focusing on the chemical investigation of
Colletotrichum brevisporum ,
and the first report of bianthrones isolated from the
Colletotrichum
genus.

sec.title: 2. Results and discussion
sec.p:
The molecular formula of brevianthrone A1 ( 1 ) was determined to be C 36 H 34 O 10 , based on the HRESIMS analysis, which showed a strong sodiated adduct ion peak at m/z 649.2049. The UV–vis spectrum showed maxima at 359 and 277 nm , consistent with the UV spectra of bianthrones (
;
). In the 13 C NMR spectrum, only 18 signals were observed in the spectrum, indicating that the molecule was likely a symmetrical dimer. The carbon signals showed similarities to the spectroscopic data found for bianthrone A 1 , isolated from the plant
Vismia orientalis ( Mbwambo et al., 2004 )
, exhibiting typical chemical shifts for the bianthrone skeleton ( Table 1 ), including oxygenated
sp 2
carbons (
δC
164.6, 165.4, 161.8). In addition to signals consistent with a bianthrone core, a methoxy group (
δC
55.7), and signals belonging to a 2-hydroxypropyl side chain (
δC
45.8, 68.1, 23.2) were also observed. The 1 H NMR spectrum showed four characteristic aromatic signals (
δH
6.39, 6.04, 6.19, 6.72), two hydroxy protons (
δH
12.08, 11.82) and the signals arising from 2-hydroxypropyl side chain, which suggested that the compound was composed of two nalgiovensin-like subunits. The position of substituents was confirmed by HMBC correlations ( Fig. 2 ). 1-OH was assigned based on its correlation to C-1, C-2 and C-9a, while 8-OH showed correlations to C-7 and C-8. The position of the methoxy group at C-3 was confirmed by its correlation to C-3 and correlation from H-2 to the methoxy carbon. The position of the 2-hydroxypropyl side chain was confirmed based on correlations from H-11 to the aromatic carbons C-5,6,7 ( Fig. 2 ). In contrast to the deshielded quinone carbon of nalgiovensin (
δC
181.9), C-10 of compound 1 was at much lower chemical shift (
δC
56.5), consistent with the presence of a C10–C10 ′ linked bianthrone, instead of an anthraquinone. HMBC correlations from H-10 to C-4, 4a, 5, 8a, 9a confirmed the connectivity of the two subunits as shown. After being dissolved in chloroform, brevianthrone A1 ( 1 ) formed X-ray diffraction suitable crystals. X-ray analysis confirmed the structure ( Fig. 3 ), while the Flack parameter of 0.08(9) allowed assignment of the absolute configuration of 1 as 10 R , 10 ′ R , 12 S , 12 ′ S . Comparison of experimental and calculated ECD spectra of 1 show excellent agreement ( Fig. 4 ).

Brevianthrones A2 ( 2 ) and A3 ( 3 ) were isolated as an inseparable mixture, in a 1:2 ratio. The molecular formulae of the two compounds were both C 36 H 34 O 10 , based on the HRESIMS analysis, and also possessed a UV spectrum consistent with the presence of a bianthrone core. In the 1 H NMR spectrum, the same key resonances were observed as for compound 1 , while the HMBC spectrum established the same connectivity. Thus, compounds 2 and 3 were determined to be stereoisomers of 1 , differing in configuration at C-10 and C-10 ′ . In the 13 C NMR analysis, three sets of signals were observed in an approximately 1:1:1 ratio. This was attributed to one set of signals from the chiral brevianthrone A2 ( 2 ), and two sets of signals from the mesomer brevianthrone A3 ( 3 ), present in a 1:2 ratio. Diasteromeric bianthrones have been obtained as mixtures before: Form et al. isolated inseparable wentibianthrones from the lake-derived fungus
Aspergillus wentii ( Form et al., 2019 )
. In contrast, similar isomeric compounds, the allianthrones, have been reported from co-culture of two developmental stages of a marine-derived fungus
Aspergillus alliaceus ( Mandelare et al., 2018 )
, and all three isomers could be separated using achiral reversed-phase chromatography.

Brevianthrone B1 ( 4 ) was isolated as a pure compound, and displayed a similar UV absorbance to compounds 1–3 , suggesting that it was also a bianthrone. Its molecular formula was determined to be C 37 H 36 O 10 , based on HRESIMS analysis, which showed a strong ion at m/z 663.2189 [M+Na] + . In the 13 C NMR two sets of paired signals were observed, indicating that compound 4 was asymmetrical dimer consisting of two structurally related monomers. Further inspection of the 1 H-NMR and 13 C-NMR spectra ( Table 2 ) allowed the assignment of two anthrone moieties that are structurally related to the known anthraquinones 8 and 9 . The 1 H-NMR and 13 C-NMR spectra were similar to those of brevianthrone A1 ( 1 ), except one of the hydroxy groups in compound 1 was replaced by a methoxy group in compound 4 . The molecular weight difference of 14 amu between compound 1 and compound 4 was consistent with the presence of an additional methoxy group, the position of which was confirmed by an HMBC correlation to C-1. Comparison of computed ECD spectra of 4 showed an excellent qualitative agreement with calculated spectra, allowing for assignment of absolute stereochemistry of the stereocenters as 10 R , 10 ′ R , 12 S , 12 ′ S .

Brevianthrones B2 ( 5 ) and B3 ( 6 ) were isolated as a 1:1-mixture of diastereomers. They displayed the characteristic UV absorbances of bianthrones, and were also isomers of 4 , based on the HRESIMS analysis ( m/z 663.2176 [M+Na] + ). After analyzing the NMR data, the planar structures were determined to be the same as for compound 4 .
a Spectra were recorded at 400 MHz for 1 H NMR and 100 MHz for 13 C NMR in CDCl 3 .

Brevianthrone B4 ( 7 ) was isolated as another diastereomer of brevianthrone B1 ( 4 ). The molecular formula was determined to be C 37 H 36 O 10 , based on the HRESIMS analysis ( m/z 663.2182 [M+Na] + ). The HRMS data, UV spectrum, 1D and 2D NMR data was almost identical to those of compound 4 , and indicated that the compound, brevianthrone B4 ( 7 ), was a stereoisomer of brevianthrone B1 ( 4 ). Comparison of experimental ECD spectra with spectra calculated for 10 R , 10 ′ S , 12 S , 12 ′ S allowed for confident assignment of the absolute configuration ( Fig. 4 ).

To further confirm our hypothesis that 2/3 and 5/6 were both twocompound mixtures, these two samples were subjected to analysis using chiral HPLC . Following analysis on a Chiralcel OD-H column, compounds 2 and 3 could be separated as two peaks ( 2 : tR = 32.2; 3 : tR = 27.4), with a peak area ratio close to 1:2 ( Fig. S1 ). For compounds 5 and 6 ( tR = 24.4, tR = 31.5), two peaks were also visible, with a peak area ratio of approximately 1:1 ( Fig. S2 ).

Thus, in the current study, we have used simulation of ECD spectra to determine the absolute configurations of 4 and 7 , as well as corroborate the absolute configuration of 1 . Fig. 4 shows experimental spectra for 1 , 4 , and
7 in
comparison to sTDDFT calculated spectra at the CAMB3LYP//GNF2-xTB level with ALPB solvation in acetonitrile. The calculated and experimental spectra for each show excellent qualitative agreement and allow for corroboration of the absolute configuration of 1 as 10 R , 10 ′ R , 12 S , 12 ′ S . The isomeric brevianthrones A2 ( 2 ) and A3 ( 3 ), isolated as an inseparable mixture were thus assigned as the 10 S , 10 ′ S , 12 S , 12 ′ S , and 10 S , 10 ′ R , 12 S , 12 ′ S , isomers, respectively. ECD was also used to confirm the configurations of brevianthrones B1 ( 4 ) and B4 ( 7 ) as 10 R , 10 ′ R , 12 S , 12 ′ S and 10 R , 10 ′ S , 12 S , 12 ′ S respectively. By elimination, that suggests that brevianthrones B2 ( 5 ) and B3 ( 6 ), obtained as an inseparable mixture, must be the 10 S , 10 ′ S , 12 S , 12 ′ S and 10 S , 10 ′ R , 12 S , 12 ′ S stereoisomers.

The crude extracts and all pure compounds were tested for antimicrobial activity against eight bacteria and two fungi (Table S3), unfortunately, no activity was observed against any of the test strains. Compounds 1 , 8 and 9 were tested for cytotoxicity against human breast cancer (MDA-MB-231) and human liver cancer (HepG-2) cell lines, however none of the compounds showed obvious cytotoxicity at the concentrations tested (0–100 μM).

sec.title: 3. Conclusion
sec.p:
In summary, seven undescribed bianthrones along with two known anthraquinones were isolated from
C. brevisporum
. The structures of the undescribed bianthrones were elucidated by analysis of 1D and 2D NMR spectra and HRMS data. Based on the fact that the nalgiovensin ( 8 ) and 1-methoxy-nalgiovensin ( 9 ) are biogenetic building blocks of the brevianthrones ( 1–7 ), it is assumed that the orientation at C-12/12 ′ is S . The absolute configuration of brevianthrones ( 1–7 ) at C-10 was determined by ECD simulation, with the support of the X-ray crystallography of brevianthone A1 ( 1 ). The mixture of isomers observed is consistent with an achiral dimerization mechanism. Our findings enrich the chemical diversity of bianthrones to date, and continue to highlight the
Colletotrichum
genus as a potential source of new chemistry, not just as plant pathogens. Compounds were tested for antimicrobial and cytotoxic properties, but none showed any bioactivity.

sec.title: Orphanage
Orphanage
sec.p: a Spectra were recorded at 400 MHz for 1 H NMR and 100 MHz for 13 C NMR in CDCl 3 .

sec.title: 4.1. General
sec.p: Aseptic operations were carried out in a ZHJH-C115C Laminar hood (Zhicheng, Shanghai). Microbes were grown in a ZXSD-A1090 incubator (Zhicheng, Shanghai), and were fermented in a ZWYR-240 shakerincubator (Zhicheng, Shanghai). Optical rotations were recorded using an Anton Par Polarimeter (λ 589) using a 300 μL cell with a path length of 0.5 dm. UV data was measured on a U-3900 spectrophotometer (Hitachi, Japan ). Electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra were measured on a Bio-Logic MOS-500 spectrometer using a 1 cm path length quartz cuvette. HPLC analysis was performed on an Agilent 1260 series HPLC system using a ZORBAX SB-C18 (3.5 μm, 4.6 × 150 mm ; Agilent Technologies), Pursuit XRs5, C-18 (3.5 μm, 4.6 × 150 mm , Agilent Technologies) and Chiralcel® OD-H (5 μm, 4.6 × 250 mm , Daicel Chiral Technologies) columns. Semipreparative HPLC separation was carried out on a Shimadzu LC-20AR series HPLC instrument, using a reversed-phase C18 column (ZORBAX SB-C18, 5 μm, 9.4 × 250 mm ). NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance III 400 spectrometer. HRESIMS spectra were obtained from an Agilent 1290 UPLC system with a Bruker microTOF-Q II mass spectrometer.

sec.title: 4.2. Fungal material
4.3. Identification of plant-derived fungus
sec.p:
To identify the strain under investigation, the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region and 28S region were amplified and sequenced using the following primers: ITS1/ITS4, LR6/LROR. The results were analyzed and compared to database sequences at National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI). The data revealed 100% identity to the ITS region of a fungal isolate (accession number JN943072.1), and 99.8% identity to 28S region of a fungal isolate (accession number NG_067524.1). Both accession numbers were derived from the known species
C. brevisporum
. The ITS sequence was submitted to Genbank under accession number MW445186 . Phylogenetic trees were constructed and analyzed by neighbor-joining statistical method ( Fig. S3 and S 4 ).

sec.title: 4.4. Fermentation
sec.p: The fungal strain was grown on Potato Dextrose Broth (PDB) media (Solarbio, Beijing ), which contained potato powder (6.0 g/L) and glucose (20.0 g/L) in distilled water (1 L) in a 2 L Erlenmeyer flask. Media was autoclaved for 20 min at 120 ◦ C. Fermentation was performed in twenty flasks for ten days (total 20 L) at 30 ◦ C in the shaker with rotating speed of 120 rpm/min.

sec.title: 4.5. Extraction and isolation
sec.p: The extract was subjected to fractionation using a silica gel column ( 25.8 g ) with eluents of increasing polarity using dichloromethane: methanol (400:1, 300:1, 200:1, 100:1, 80:1, 40:1, 20:1, 1:1, 0:1) to obtain a total of 9 fractions (Fr 1–9). Final purification was performed by reverse phase HPLC with acetonitrile/H 2 O as a mobile phase, at 8 mL/ min. Fr.2 was purified by semipreparative HPLC , using isocratic conditions at 60% ACN to yield compound 9 (3.0 mg). Fr.4 was purified by semipreparative HPLC , using a gradient from 36 to 42% ACN to yield compound 8 (10.0 mg). Fr.5 was separated by semipreparative HPLC under isocratic condition at 48% ACN to yield pure compound 1 ( 6.4 mg ) and 2/3 ( 12.2 mg ). Fr. 6 was separated by semipreparative HPLC under isocratic condition at 38% ACN to yield compounds 4 ( 2.4 mg ), and 5/6 (4.0 mg), and 7 (2.0 mg).

sec.title:
4.5.1. Brevianthrone A1 (1) ( tR
= 14.8)
sec.p: Light yellow solid; [α] 20 D +2 (c 0.05, MeCN); UV–vis (MeCN) λ max (log ε ): 359 (1.96), 277 (1.95) nm; ECD (c 0.05, MeCN) λ max (Δε): 365 (+0.90), 304 (5.79), 277 (+2.86), 254 (0.99), 232 (+2.85), 216 (8.46), 200 (+4.66) nm; 1 H NMR (CDCl 3 , 400 MHz) and 13 C NMR (CDCl 3 , 100 MHz) spectra, see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 649.2049 [M+Na] + (calcd for C 36 H 34 NaO 10 , 649.2044).

sec.title:
4.5.2. Brevianthrone A2/3 (2/3) ( tR
= 15.1)
sec.p: Light yellow solid; [α] 20 D +8 (c 0.1, MeCN); UV–vis (MeCN) λ max (log ε ): 360 (2.40), 278 (2.35) nm; ECD (c 0.1, MeCN) λ max (Δε): 367 (2.14), 305 (+4.60), 279 (5.19), 233 (5.00), 216 (+9.75), 200 (5.47) nm; 1 H NMR (CDCl 3 , 400 MHz) and 13 C NMR (CDCl 3 , 100 MHz) spectra, see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 649.2072 [M+Na] + (calcd for C 36 H 34 NaO 10 , 649.2044).

sec.title:
4.5.3. Brevianthrone B1 (4) ( tR
= 13.4)
sec.p: Dark yellow solid; [α] 20 D 27 (c 0.1, MeCN); UV–vis (MeCN) λ max (log ε ): 351 (2.27), 277 (2.22) nm; ECD (c 0.1, MeCN) λ max (Δε): 384 (5.02), 348 (+5.11), 307 (10.7), 263 (+6.74), 232 (+9.02), 216 (7.60), 200 (+16.6) nm; 1 H NMR (CDCl 3 , 400 MHz) and 13 C NMR (CDCl 3 , 100 MHz) spectra, see Table 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 663.2189 [M+Na] + (calcd for C 37 H 36 NaO 10 , 663.2201).

sec.title:
4.5.4. Brevianthrone B2/B3 (5/6) ( tR
= 13.5)
sec.p: Dark yellow solid; [α] 20 D +26 (c 0.1, MeCN); UV–vis (MeCN) λ max (log ε ): 350 (2.56), 276 (2.58) nm; 1 H NMR (CDCl 3 , 400 MHz) and 13 C NMR (CDCl 3 , 100 MHz) spectra, see Table 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 663.2176 [M+Na] + (calcd for C 37 H 36 NaO 10 , 663.2201).

sec.title:
4.5.6. Nalgiovensin (8) ( tR
= 14.7)
sec.p: Orange-yellow needle crystals; [α] 20 D +12 (c 0.1, CHCl 3 ); UV–vis (CHCl 3 ) λ max (log ε ): 438 (2.18), 287 (2.36), 265 (2.40), 249 (2.41) nm; HRESIMS m/z 351.0853 [M+Na] + (calcd for C 18 H 16 NaO 6 , 351.0839).

sec.title:
4.5.7. Methoxy-nalgiovensin (9) ( tR
= 12.6)
sec.p: Yellow needle crystals; [α] 20 D +10 (c 0.1, CHCl 3 ); UV–vis (CHCl 3 ) λ max (log ε ): 424 (2.13), 271 (2.53), 245 (2.40) nm; HRESIMS m/z 343.1179 [M+H] + (calcd for C 19 H 19 O 6 , 343.1176).

sec.title: 4.6. Computational details
Orphanage
sec.p: 4.7. Chiral HPLC analysis

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Samples were analyzed using Agilent 1260 normal-phase HPLC equipped with an analytical CHIRALCEL® OD-H column, with hexane/ isopropanol as the mobile phase. Samples were run at isocratic conditions (20% isopropanol) for 60 min at 1 mL/min.

sec.title: 4.8. X-ray crystallography
4.8.1. Crystallographic data for compound 1
sec.p: C 36 H 24 O 10 , 2C 36 H 34 O 10 , M = 1253.26, 0.2 × 0.03 × 0.03 mm , T = 159.99 (10) K, monoclinic, space group P21, a = 11.5419(2)Å, b = 19.8213(4)Å, c = 14.2445(3)Å, α = 90 ◦ , β = 113.029(2) ◦ , γ = 90 ◦ , V = 999.09(11)Å 3 , Z = 2, ρc = 1.388 g /cm 3 , μ (Cu) = 0.840 mm 1 , F (000) = 1320.0, 2 θ max = 146.022 ◦ , 33,639 reflections, 11,450 independent reflections [ Rint = 0.0548, Rsigma = 0.0565], R1 = 0.0459, wR2 = 0.1092, and GOF = 1.010 for 11,450 reflections (849 parameters) with I ≥ 2σ (I), R1 = 0.0587, wR2 = 0.1173 and GOF = 1.010 for all reflections, the Flack = 0.08(9), max/min residual electron density 0.41/- 0.18 e Å 3 . Crystallography data have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC). Deposition number: CCDC 2068588.

sec.title: 4.9. Biological testing
sec.p: Procedures for well diffusion assays and cytotoxic activity testing are provided in the supporting information.

sec.title: Declaration of competing interest
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p: This work was funded in part by an award from the Research Fund for International Young Scientists (81850410550) from the National Science Foundation of China , and by startup funds from Tianjin University. The authors would like to thank S. Loesgen for her valuable comments during preparation of the manuscript, and Y. Zhao for providing the cell lines for cytotoxicity screening. The authors also acknowledge J. Xu and Y. Gao at the analytical center of the School of Pharmaceutical Science and Technology for their assistance in the acquisition of X-ray crystal structures and MS data, respectively.

sec.title: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2021.112792.
